Given the following information, what is the time to reach at the Point of Safe Return (PSR)?
Departure Time: 14:00
Wind: 270º/30 kt
Flight Track: 270º
TAS: 100 kt
Safe Endurance: 3 h

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield, arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the fuel tanks
The time an aircraft takes to reach at PSR is given by the formula: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H), where: E = Safe Endurance based on the available fuel, H = GS Home and O = GS Out

For this question, the wind direction is exactly opposite to the track, thus the Groundspeed Out (O) is: O = TAS - Wind component = 100 kt - 30 kt = 70 kt and the Groundspeed Home (H): H = TAS + Wind component = 100 kt + 30 kt = 130 kt
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield, arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the fuel tanks. The time an aircraft takes to reach at PSR is given by the formula: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H), where: E = Safe Endurance based on the available fuel, H = GS Home and O = GS Out. For this question, the wind direction is exactly opposite to the track, thus the Groundspeed Out (O) is: O = TAS - Wind component = 100 kt - 30 kt = 70 kt and the Groundspeed Home (H): H = TAS + Wind component = 100 kt + 30 kt = 130 kt. So, substituting all the known values, we get: Time taken to PSR = (E x H) / (O + H) = (3 hr x 130 kt) / (70 kt + 130 kt) = 1.95 hr or 1 hr 57 min. Therefore, the aircraft will reach overhead PSR at: 14:00 + 01:57 = 15:57.

VHF Direction Finding VDF VDF provides a means of determining the aircraft bearing from a ground station

learning.explanation: The answer is VDF and not ATC clearance even though the frequency falls in the VHF Communication range, the NOTAM would mention an alternate frequency if the voice channel transmitter was not available. VHF Direction Finding VDF VDF provides a means of determining the aircraft bearing from a ground station. VDF stations are capable of measuring the direction of arrival of radio transmissions from aircraft. In earlier days, such a service operated in MF, HF, and VHF bands. Today, the service (for civil aviation) operates on frequencies from 118 to 137 MHz in the VHF band. These frequencies are identical with the working frequencies of the aircraft communication radio. If the communications transmitter on an aircraft is tuned to the VDF frequency and the transmitter is activated, the aerials at the VDF unit will detect the incoming transmission and each aerial element will feed a signal to the VDF receiver. Since the aerial elements will all be at slightly different distances from the source of the signal, each will detect a slightly different phase of that signal at the same instant. On some VDF units a simple digital read out gives the bearing. A ground DF station can give true or magnetic bearings. It is common to use the so-called «Q-codes»: QTE True bearing from the station QDR Magnetic bearing from the station QDM Magnetic bearing to the station QTF Position of a station taken by bearings from D/F stations QUJ True bearing to the station In practice, only QDM and QDR are normally used. The accuracy of the bearing is measured in degrees. Bearings are categorised, in accordance with the ICAO defined classifications, as given in the following list: Class A accurate within ± 2° Class B accurate within ± 5° Class C accurate within ± l0° Class D accuracy less than Class C Due to topography, some VDF stations are approved for use within certain sectors only. In that case, specific information for that aerodrome will be given in AIP. Stations that are listed in the AIP provide a ‘homing’ service. Generally the class of bearing is no worse than class B. (Many states will not permit Class C & D bearings to be provided). Ground DF stations should not be used as en-route navigation aids. Source: nordian.net

key_points: POINT OF EQUAL TIME: The Point of Equal Time (PET) is the point between two aerodromes from which it takes the same time to fly to either aerodrome
For the still air case, the point of equal time is half way between the two aerodromes

learning.explanation: POINT OF EQUAL TIME: The Point of Equal Time (PET) is the point between two aerodromes from which it takes the same time to fly to either aerodrome. For the still air case, the point of equal time is half way between the two aerodromes. This is not likely and so the PET is not half way between the two aerodromes. The calculation of the PET is based on a ratio of the groundspeed to the destination and groundspeed back to base. As there’s a wind coming from North west so it will be tail wind for the way from NewYork to Amsterdam and will make the flight faster, however in the way back that will be headwind and will make the flight longer which makes the point of equal time move closer to New York. (Remember point of equal time always moves into wind)

Given the following information, at what time will the PET be reached?

Wind: 090°/20 kt
Departure time: 12:00

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 200 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 270º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 220 kt. GS out: 090º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 180 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Distance to PET = (GS home x Distance) / (GS out + GS home) Distance to PET = (220 x 1000) / (180 + 220) Distance to PET = 550 NM Time to PET = Distance to PET / GS out Time to PET = 550 / 180 = 3 h 3 min PET will be reached at: Departure time + Time to PET = 12 h + 3 h 3 = 15 h 3

content.question: Where can you, as a pilot, find information about the GNSS, which is not available at the destination airfield?

key_points: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) refers to a constellation of satellites providing signals from space that transmit positioning and timing data to GNSS receivers
The receivers then use this data to determine location
It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight
learning.explanation: Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) refers to a constellation of satellites providing signals from space that transmit positioning and timing data to GNSS receivers. The receivers then use this data to determine location. It is important before flight to check that there will be enough satellites visible for an accurate position at all stages of the flight. This GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages, which provide updates on the GPS constellation. Also, GNSS can be augmented by GBAS and SBAS and NOTAMs must be checked to ensure they are available for the time of usage. Augmentation such as GBAS, SBAS and RAIM check for errors and correct them and/or notify the flight deck. Furthermore, GNSS NOTAM provide information on individual satellite outages or temporary unavailability of service due to testing or anomalies and service outages at specific airports/airspaces. Therefore, the availability of the relevant satellites and any potential outages must be checked before flight.

content.question:
Given:
Distance from departure to destination: 150 NM
Safe Endurance: 2.4 h
True Track: 250
W/V: 280/15
TAS: 120 kt
What is the distance of the PSR from the departure point?

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination

Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 280º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 120 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 070º 5. Note that this heading would result in 3ºR drift and a track of 073º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 070º. This occurs at a heading of 067º with 4ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 133 kt. GS out: 250º 5. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 246º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 250º. This occurs at a heading of 254º with 4ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 107 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 2.4 x 133 / 107 + 133 = 1.33 h To find the distance from the departure airport to the PSR, we simply multiply the time to PSR by the GS OUT: 1.33 hrs × 107 kts = 142 NM.

Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 215º 5. Note that this heading would result in 9ºL drift and a track of 206º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 215º. This occurs at a heading of 224º with 6ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 88 kt. GS out: 035º 5. Note that this heading would result in 6ºR drift and a track of 041º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 035º. This occurs at a heading of 029º with 6ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 121 kt. content.question: What is the difference between GNSS planned and unplanned outages?

options.D: Planned outages are notified in advance.

key_points: Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) is an advisory message to inform users of a change in the GPS constellation
These messages are released 72 hours in advance of planned maintenance
These messages are also used to notify users of unscheduled outages
learning.explanation: Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) is an advisory message to inform users of a change in the GPS constellation. These messages are released 72 hours in advance of planned maintenance. These messages are also used to notify users of unscheduled outages. General NANUs can be used to disseminate general GPS information. Outages come in two varieties: planned and unplanned. Planned are all the activities/events that have been scheduled and that could potentially have an impact on the Signal-in-Space (SiS) and/or the performance levels. Planned NAGUs aim to inform users about the activity/event with a reasonable advance notice, ahead of their occurrence. The planned outages, in space or ground segment, can potentially cause an outage of the broadcast satellite SiS. A planned outage will be announced ahead of time and usually means some sort of maintenance is taking place. Unplanned are all the activities/events that have an impact on the SiS and/or the performance levels that have not been scheduled and could not be foreseen in advance, before their occurrence. The aim of unplanned NAGUs is to inform users about the activity/event within a reasonable time, after their occurrence. The difference between the planned and unplanned outages of GPS is that a planned outage is well recognisable during flight preparation, because relevant monitoring tools and NOTAMs will most probably indicate some problems. On the other hand, in case of unplanned outage, it is possible that the pilot will become aware mid-flight that integrity is lost. Therefore, the pilot should develop and maintain good practise in using backup conventional navigation whenever possible.

options.B: Do not check NOTAMs because RAIM concerns both EGNOS and all GNSS, making additional checks unnecessary.

options.D: Check NOTAMs specifically for updates on LNAV/VNAV that RAIM does not cover.

key_points: Before flight it is important to check that you will have coverage from enough satellites throughout all stages of your flight
To do this, you must ensure planned outages, maintenance or orbital corrections are not expected at the time of flight

learning.explanation: Before flight it is important to check that you will have coverage from enough satellites throughout all stages of your flight. To do this, you must ensure planned outages, maintenance or orbital corrections are not expected at the time of flight. This GNSS achievability can be verified by checking NOTAMs and the Notice Advisory to Navstar Users (NANU) messages, which provide updates on the GPS constellation. RAIM functions by monitoring the real-time satellite signal strength and integrity in order to ensure reliable GNSS position tracking. RAIM alone gives current conditions and does not warn of planned outages. For predictions, you could use the AUGUR RAIM prediction tool, which would inform you of when the satellite signals would be inadequate for an accurate position fix over a certain area, however these prediction tools mainly focus on satellite geometry and whether or not there are a sufficient number of satellites. Temporary degradations in signal strength/availability caused by GNSS interference testing for example, are usually only stated in NOTAMs. These NOTAMs specify the areas and times where signal degradation may occur due to non-satellite-related factors. Since these disruptions are external and temporary, they won't be shown in RAIM predictions, which mostly assess satellite performance.

content.question: An aircraft is scheduled to fly from Brussels (EBBR) to Malaga (LEMG) and the crew intend to use the GBAS Landing System (GLS) approach onto Runway 13 at LEMG. What is the appropriate source of information on the availability of GBAS augmentation at the estimated time of arrival?

options.C: The AUGUR GPS RAIM prediction tool

key_points: GBAS - GROUND BASED AUGMENTATION SYSTEM GBAS is a system that attempts to reduce the natural errors within the GNSS system by providing very localised augmentation to the satellite signals, via a VHF data broadcast (VDB) that a suitably equipped aircraft can receive and use to fix any position errors
It is also called "differential GPS", and can correct for errors induced by satellite clocks, ephemeris and ionospheric propagation to make the augmented GNSS signal very accurate
The GBAS can also, like its satellite based cousin, SBAS, give integrity warnings about faulty satellites, as it should be able to detect this at the nearby antennas
learning.explanation: GBAS - GROUND BASED AUGMENTATION SYSTEM GBAS is a system that attempts to reduce the natural errors within the GNSS system by providing very localised augmentation to the satellite signals, via a VHF data broadcast (VDB) that a suitably equipped aircraft can receive and use to fix any position errors. It is also called "differential GPS", and can correct for errors induced by satellite clocks, ephemeris and ionospheric propagation to make the augmented GNSS signal very accurate. The GBAS can also, like its satellite based cousin, SBAS, give integrity warnings about faulty satellites, as it should be able to detect this at the nearby antennas. GBAS is limited in the fact that it is very short range, spanning approximately 30km away from the relevant ground station (which is generally an airport). The operation of GBAS allows it to work in the same way as an ILS approach, down to 200ft minimums currently (but with the ability to carry out full auto-lands with appropriate legislation), and this is called the GBAS Landing System or GLS, and is a precision approach. It is tuned using a 5 digit channel number that picks up the correct VHF datalink signals for that approach. The availability of GBAS augmentation depends solely on the airport in question, in this case, Malaga. They are the ones who run the GBAS receivers, ground station and VDB transmitter, and therefore will mark any planned unserviceabilities as NOTAMs. It is quite tempting to choose the AUGUR RAIM prediction as the correct answer, and this might give the pilot an idea as to how many satelllites should be available for the GNSS system, but this is not what is being asked in the question.

With 3.5 hours’ total endurance on board, and a wind velocity of 270°/20 kt, a pilot has to travel over a distance of 200 NM on a track of 270°T.
If the TAS is 100 kt and the pilot must land with 30 minutes’ worth of fuel on board, what is the distance to the Point of Safe Return PSR, and how long will it take to get there

key_points: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks
If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination

Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
learning.explanation: The Point of Safe Return (PSR) is the last point on a route at which it is possible to return to the departure airfield arriving back with the required fuel reserves still available in the tanks. If the pilot chooses to continue past the PSR, he is now committed to landing at your destination. Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Where, E = Safe endurance based on available fuel; H = Ground speed home; 0 = Ground speed out Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. 1. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 090º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 120 kt. GS out: 270º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 80 kt. We can now apply the formulas: Time (to PSR) = E x H / 0 + H Time to PSR = 3 x 120 / 80 + 120 = 1.8 h = 108 min To find the distance from the departure airport to the PSR, we simply multiply the time to PSR by the GS OUT: 1.8 h × 80 kt = 144 NM. Note: If the Pilot must land with 30 minutes of fuel remaining => our safe endurance will be total endurance - 30 min.

Determine the true altitude to make sure that the Minimum Obstacle Clearance Altitude (MOCA) is maintained. Given:

MOCA: 3 700 ft
Cruising level: FL050
OAT: ISA - 15ºC
QNH: 1 004 hPa
Aerodrome elevation: 1 500 ft

key_points: True Altitude = Indicated Altitude (standard pressure) + Pressure Correction + Temperature Correction (1) Pressure Correction: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than Indicated Altitude
If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than Indicated Altitude

1013 – 1004 = 9 hPa 9 hPa x 30 ft = 270 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 9 hPa lower than standard, therefore, True altitude is 9 hPa lower than Indicated altitude => 5 000 ft - 270 ft = 4 730 ft
learning.explanation: True Altitude = Indicated Altitude (standard pressure) + Pressure Correction + Temperature Correction (1) Pressure Correction: If QNH is higher than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is higher than Indicated Altitude. If QNH is lower than 1013 hPa => True Altitude is lower than Indicated Altitude. 1013 – 1004 = 9 hPa 9 hPa x 30 ft = 270 ft With regards to this question, QNH is 9 hPa lower than standard, therefore, True altitude is 9 hPa lower than Indicated altitude => 5 000 ft - 270 ft = 4 730 ft. (2) Temperature Correction: Rule of Thumb: correction of 4% for each 10º deviation from ISA (1% for each 2.5ºC) If temperature is warmer than ISA => True Altitude is higher than IA. If temperature is colder than ISA => True Altitude is lower than IA. => Temperature Error Correction is only applied above QFE Datum (Aerodrome Level) – Column of air between the aircraft and the meteo station. The aircraft is 4 730 ft – 1 500 ft = 3 230 ft Above Aerodrome Level (AAL) For ISA -15ºC, correction equals 6%: 3 230 ft x 6% = 194 ft As ISA deviation is negative (-15ºC), True altitude is lower than Indicated altitude. Therefore, True Altitude = Indicated altitude(QNH) - Temperature error correction => 4 730 ft - 194 ft = 4 536 ft Learning Objective 033.04.02.02.02: Confirm true altitudes from given atmospheric data to ensure that statutory minimum clearance is attained.

Set wind direction to 320º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 214 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 40 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. GS home: 170º 5. Note that this heading would result in 5ºL drift and a track of 165º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 170º. This occurs at a heading of 175º with 5ºL drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 248 kt. GS out: 350º 5. Note that this heading would result in 7ºR drift and a track of 357º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 350º. This occurs at a heading of 343º with 5ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 178 kt. learning.explanation: Satellite Based Augmentation Systems (SBAS) provide a high level of accuracy over a wide area (in contrast to GBAS, which provides accuracy to a small area), using satellites to send correction data to the aircraft. There are four systems under operation, which work on the same basic principle. One of them is the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) in Western Europe and the Mediterranean. EGNOS uses three geostationary INMARSAT (International Maritime Satellite Organisation) satellites, which broadcast GPS signals, provide horizontal accuracy of around 0.7 m and vertically around 1.1 m and it, also, alerts users within 6 seconds if a GPS malfunction occurs. LPV is a 3D approach with vertical guidance (APV), like a conventional ILS, but using GNSS augmented by SBAS, with no barometric input. According to the NOTAM, the EGNOS system, which is an SBAS system, is not available for LPV approaches, thus for LPV minima.

learning.explanation: ITEM 19 - Endurance After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes. Fuel Endurance in Item 19 of ATC Flight Plan is for Search Radius, in case an Aircraft is reported missing or overdue. content.question:
Refer to figure.
Use the following information to determine what would be entered into ITEM 19 ENDURANCE of the ICAO Flight Plan form.
Flight rules: VFR
Environment: Non-hostile
Taxi Fuel: 20 kg
Trip distance: 412 NM
Average trip TAS: 140 kt
Average Trip Fuel flow: 430 kg/h
Average wind component: +15 kt
Time to alternate: 25 minutes
Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes holding T/O
Fuel: minimum required

key_points: After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes
Note: the taxi fuel is not included in the endurance figure
Endurance by definition is the time the aircraft can remain airborne on the fuel contained in the tanks - therefore disregard the taxi fuel and time
learning.explanation: After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes. Note: the taxi fuel is not included in the endurance figure. Endurance by definition is the time the aircraft can remain airborne on the fuel contained in the tanks - therefore disregard the taxi fuel and time. It includes all of the usable fuel on board, including any reserves. Endurance = the time airborne before the tanks run dry. TAS=140 kt, if the average wind is +15, it means it is tailwind, so Ground speed => 140 + 15 = 155 kts Trip distance 412 NM = 155 * t (time) = 2.66 hours =>160 minutes We also need to find Contingency Fuel => if the trip time 2.66 hours and fuel flow per hour is 430 kg, we will burn (430 *2.66) = 1 144 kg, Contingency fuel 5% trip fuel =>1 144 * 0.05 = 57 kg If we burn 430 kg per hour, we can airborne 8 minutes with 57 kg contingency fuel. Trip: 160 minutes Contingency Fuel: 8 minutes Alternate: 25 minutes Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes Total =>223 minutes => 3 hour 43 minutes

content.question:
The navigation plan reads:
Trip fuel: 100 kg
Flight time: 1 h 35 min
Taxi fuel: 3 kg
Block fuel: 181 kg
The endurance on the ICAO flight plan should read:

key_points: ITEM 19 - Endurance After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes
Fuel Endurance in Item 19 of ATC Flight Plan is for Search Radius, in case an Aircraft is reported missing or overdue

It must be the Total Fuel Endurance of the Aircraft, and must take into account the Total Fuel On-Board - it is the time the aircraft can remain airborne, and, therefore, includes all usable fuel onboard (including any reserves)
learning.explanation: ITEM 19 - Endurance After E/ INSERT a 4-figure group giving the fuel endurance in hours and minutes. Fuel Endurance in Item 19 of ATC Flight Plan is for Search Radius, in case an Aircraft is reported missing or overdue. It must be the Total Fuel Endurance of the Aircraft, and must take into account the Total Fuel On-Board - it is the time the aircraft can remain airborne, and, therefore, includes all usable fuel onboard (including any reserves). However, it does not include taxi fuel. Calculate the Fuel Flow: Fuel Flow = Trip Fuel / Flight Time Fuel Flow = 100 kg / 1h 35 min = 63.16 kg/h Calculate Total Fuel onboard at take off (excluding Taxi Fuel): Take-Off Fuel = Block Fuel - Taxi Fuel = 181 kg - 3 kg = 178 kg Calculate Endurance: Endurance = Take-Off Fuel / Fuel Flow = 178 kg : 63.16 kg/h = 2 h 49 min

content.question: When a pilot fills in an ATC flight plan, he/she must indicate the wake turbulence category. This category is a function of which mass?

1 Wake turbulence categories of aircraft 4

Computerized Flight Plans: Correct statements regarding computer flight plans: 1. The computer can file the ATC flight plan. 2. The computer calculates alternate fuel sufficient for a missed approach, climb, cruise, descent and approach and landing at the destination alternate. Incorrect statements regarding computer flight plans: 1. In the event of inflight re-routing the computer produces a new plan. 2. content.question:
A pilot has planned a track of 276° (T) taking into account the following forecast wind: 240°(T)/15 kt. But, during the cruise phase, he/she realizes that the actual wind is not as forecasted, but it is 290°(T)/25 kt. Which statement below is correct/incorrect, assuming that the actual airspeed is the same as the planned airspeed?
1. With a lower groundspeed, the actual timings will be later than the planned timings.
2. The wind correction angle must be altered from a value to the right to a value to the left.

key_points: Drift is the angle from heading to the actual track (track made good)
It is called left (port) dirft, when the track made good is less than the heading and right (starboard), when the track is greater than the heading
Wind Correction Angle (WCA) is the angle difference from the aircraft’s actual track (track made good) to its planned heading
learning.explanation: Drift is the angle from heading to the actual track (track made good). It is called left (port) dirft, when the track made good is less than the heading and right (starboard), when the track is greater than the heading. Wind Correction Angle (WCA) is the angle difference from the aircraft’s actual track (track made good) to its planned heading. It is of equal amount with the drift, but with different sign. Statement 1: CORRECT With either the forecast wind 240°(T)/15 kt, or the actual wind 290°(T)/25 kt, the aircraft with a track of 276° (T) will experience a headwind componet in both cases. The headwind component because of the forecast wind is: 15 kt x cos (276° - 240°) = 12 kt. The headwind component because of the actual wind is: 25 kt x cos (290° - 276°) = 24 kt. Thus, the aircraft will actually experience a greater headwind component during the cruise phase, which will further decrease its Groundspeed and as a consequence its actual flight time will increase. Statement 2: INCORRECT Because of the forecast wind 240°(T)/15 kt, blowing from forward-left, the aircraft is expected to drift to the right. Thus, the WCA should be to the left. But, due to the actual wind 290°(T)/25 kt, blowing from forward-right, the aircraft finally drifts to the left. Thus, the WCA must be to the right. Therefore, the WCA must be altered from a value to the left to a value to the right.

A flight crew is operating a Commercial Air Transport flight and arriving in VMC overhead the holding fix on the approach towards the destination airport A when ATC tells the Commander to take up the hold and expect 17 minutes delay. Use the data below for available fuel on board when commencing the hold and find the LEGAL and preferred COMMERCIAL solution.
Alternate Fuel: 40 minutes.
Final Reserve Fuel: 30 minutes.
Extra Fuel: 10 minutes.

options.A: Immediately divert to the destination alternate since there is NOT sufficient fuel to hold for the estimated 17 minutes, thereby having extra fuel when landing at the destination alternate.
options.B: Hold for 17 minutes, and after that time if landing isn't possible, proceed to alternate using the alternate fuel remaining.
options.C: Hold 10 minutes to see effectively if it's a 17 minutes holding, and in case it is, proceed to the alternate, leaving the 30 minutes of final reserve fuel intact.
options.D: Declare minimum fuel to ATC as that will guarantee priority and ATC will ensure that the aeroplane will only hold for the available time to land with alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel.

key_points: There are two LEGAL options: Divert immediately or, As the destination is VMC, then an alternate is not required and the destination can be renominated as its own alternate
Also, taking into account: The cost of the aircraft landing at the alternate
The subsequent additional costs of repositioning the aircraft
learning.explanation: There are two LEGAL options: Divert immediately or, As the destination is VMC, then an alternate is not required and the destination can be renominated as its own alternate. Also, taking into account: The cost of the aircraft landing at the alternate. The subsequent additional costs of repositioning the aircraft. The financial and reputational costs of the passengers/cargo not being delivered at the desired destination. The preferred COMMERCIAL option is to land at the destination. According to SPO. OP.150 "Destination alternate aerodromes — aeroplanes": For IFR flights, the Pilot-In-Command shall specify at least one weather-permissible destination alternate aerodrome in the flight plan, unless: (a) the available current meteorological information indicates that, for the period from 1 hour before until 1 hour after the estimated time of arrival, or from the actual time of departure to 1 hour after the estimated time of arrival, whichever is the shorter period, the approach and landing may be made under visual meteorological conditions (VMC); or (b) the place of intended landing is isolated and: (1) an instrument approach procedure is prescribed for the aerodrome of intended landing; and (2) available current meteorological information indicates that the following meteorological conditions will exist from 2 hours before to 2 hours after the estimated time of arrival, or from the actual time of departure to 2 hours after the estimated time of arrival whichever is the shorter period: (i) a cloud base of at least 300 m (1 000 ft) above the minimum associated with the instrument approach procedure; and (ii) visibility of at least 5,5 km or of 4 km more than the minimum associated with the procedure. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The LEGAL and preferred COMMERCIAL solution is option c) Hold 10 minutes to see effectively if it's a 17 minutes holding, and in case it is, proceed to the alternate, leaving the 30 minutes of final reserve fuel intact. Option b) "Hold for 17 minutes, and after that time if landing isn't possible, proceed to alternate using the alternate fuel remaining." This scenario requires the pilots to consume 7 minutes of final reserve fuel, as they are only carrying 10 minutes of extra fuel (for holding). Option a) "Immediately divert to the destination alternate since there is NOT sufficient fuel to hold for the estimated 17 minutes, thereby having extra fuel when landing at the destination alternate." is incorrect because diverting immediately to the alternate is not necessary since the aircraft has sufficient fuel to complete the hold and land at the destination airport A with the required fuel reserves. Option d) "Declare minimum fuel to ATC as that will guarantee priority and ATC will ensure that the aeroplane will only hold for the available time to land with alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel." is incorrect because declaring minimum fuel is not necessary since the aircraft has sufficient fuel to complete the hold and land at the destination airport A with the required fuel reserves. Additionally, declaring minimum fuel when not actually necessary may cause unnecessary delays and concerns for the crew and ATC.

This question requires you to convert a compass heading to a true track
Use the following rule of thumb; Compass to true - add East
learning.explanation: This is a CDMVT question. This question requires you to convert a compass heading to a true track. Use the following rule of thumb; Compass to true - add East. Compass Heading = 252° Deviation = -3° (W) Magnetic Heading = 249° Variation = +22°E True Heading = 271° This may potentially be one of the answers, however we have the true heading, not the true track. Because we have not accounted for the INS’ drift. INS Drift = 9°R Drift right = Add the drift for track So 271° + 9° = 280° (True track)

Below TAS 176 kt on the outer scale, read CAS 140 kt on the inner scale
Using again your Flight/Nav computer, find the TAS at FL090: In the airspeed correction window, align the OAT at FL090 (M05) with 9 000 ft pressure altitude
learning.explanation: Firstly, find the CAS, using your Flight/Nav computer: In the airspeed correction window, align the OAT at FL150 (M15) with 15 000 ft pressure altitude. Below TAS 176 kt on the outer scale, read CAS 140 kt on the inner scale. Using again your Flight/Nav computer, find the TAS at FL090: In the airspeed correction window, align the OAT at FL090 (M05) with 9 000 ft pressure altitude. Above CAS 140 kt on the inner scale, read TAS 160 kt on the outer scale. To calculate the revised ETA at WPT C, the Groundspeed at FL090 is required, through your Flight/Nav computer: Place the centre dot over TAS 160 kt. Rotate the disk until wind direction 145o is under the True index. Mark wind velocity 15 kt below the centre dot. Rotate the disc until the track 335o is under the True index. The mark shows a Groundspeed of 175 kt. Thus, the sector from WPT B to WPT C will be covered in: Sector Time = Sector distance / GS = 61 NM / 175 kt = 0.35 hr or 21 min. Therefore, the revised ETA at WPT C will be: 12:12 (ATA at WPT B) + 21 min = 12:33.

content.question: An aircraft is cruising at 7 000 ft and has to descend from a Top of Descent at 7 000 ft to 2 000 ft, where the approach at the destination aerodrome will commence. The maximum rate of descent is 1 000 ft/min and the average ground speed during the descent is 180 kt. What should be the minimum horizontal distance between the Top of Descent and the destination aerodrome, so as to be at 2 000 ft 10 NM from the destination aerodrome?

key_points: Top of Descent, usually abbreviated to TOD, is the point at which the cruise phase ends and the descent phase begins
The aircraft has to descend from 7 000 ft to 2 000 ft: 7 000 ft - 2 000 ft = 5 000 ft
With a maximum rate of descent of 1000 fpm, the time to descent 5 000 ft is: 5 000 ft / 1 000 fpm = 5 minutes
learning.explanation: Top of Descent, usually abbreviated to TOD, is the point at which the cruise phase ends and the descent phase begins. The aircraft has to descend from 7 000 ft to 2 000 ft: 7 000 ft - 2 000 ft = 5 000 ft. With a maximum rate of descent of 1000 fpm, the time to descent 5 000 ft is: 5 000 ft / 1 000 fpm = 5 minutes. With an average groundspeed of 180 kt, the aircraft covers in 5 minutes, a minimum horizontal distance of: 180 kt x 5/60 hr = 15 NM. The aircraft must be at the bottom of descent 2000 ft, 10 NM from the destination aerodrome. Thus, the descent must commence: 15 NM for descent + 10 NM = 25 NM from the destination aerodrome. NOTE: The minimum horizontal distance is always covered, when descending with the maximum rate of descent.

content.question:
Refer to AMSTERDAM - Chart 10-2B from Jeppesen GSPRM 2017.
You are flying from the waypoint MOLIX to SUGOL, with 330 kt TAS, 180°/25 kt wind, fuel flow 1 800 kg/h. Your actual fuel over MOLIX is 3 000 kg. ATC asks you to hold over SUGOL for 20 minutes. What is your fuel remaining after the holding?

key_points: Few considerations: - We must know the fuel we will have onboard over SOGUL, before we start holding => We must know the amount of fuel consumed from MOLIX to SOGUL
- In order to calculate fuel consumption between MOLIX - SOGUL, we must know our Ground Speeds - these will be affected by the wind and change in track
- Track and distance information can be taken from the graph
learning.explanation: Few considerations: - We must know the fuel we will have onboard over SOGUL, before we start holding => We must know the amount of fuel consumed from MOLIX to SOGUL. - In order to calculate fuel consumption between MOLIX - SOGUL, we must know our Ground Speeds - these will be affected by the wind and change in track. - Track and distance information can be taken from the graph. (1) Let's start by calculating the Ground Speed and flight time for the two legs: MOLIX - ROBVI and ROBVI - SOGUL: Ground Speed can be calculated using the Flight computer. MOLIX - ROBVI: Track 120º, 30 NM (17 NM + 13 NM), TAS 330 kt => GS = 317 kt Flight time = 30 NM / 317 kt = 5.7 min ROBVI - SOGUL: Track 114º, 7.5 NM, TAS 330 kt => GS = 319 kt Flight time = 7.5 NM / 319 kt = 1.4 min => Total flight time = 5.7 min + 1.4 min = approx. 7 min (2) Calculate Fuel consumed between MOLIX - SOGUL: Fuel Flow: 1 800 kg/h Flight Time: 7 min Fuel consumed = 7 min x 1 800 kg/h = 210 kg (3) Calculate holding fuel: Fuel Flow: 1 800 kg/h Holding: 20 min Fuel consumed = 20 min x 1 800 kg/h = 600 kg (4) Calculate Total Fuel Consumed: Fuel consumed MOLIX - SOGUL + Holding fuel = 210 kg + 600 kg = 810 kg (5) Calculate Fuel Remaining after holding: Fuel over MOLIX - Total Fuel consumed = 3 000 kg - 810 kg = 2 190 kg

The pilot of a light twin-engined aircraft has filled in the flight log correctly for a charter flight to Nice in France, with the fuel recorded in litres. What is the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX?

key_points: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min
So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt
The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min
learning.explanation: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min. So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt. The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min. Thus, its Actual Fuel Flow is: 30 lt / 12 min = 2.5 lt/min. The FL, TAS, Track, Heading and Groundspeed remain unchanged from TORDU to EBROX. So, the Flight time from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX is: Leg distance / Actual GS = (26 NM + 14 NM) / 185 kt = 0.22 hr or 13 min. And, the fuel required from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX will be: Actual fuel flow x Flight leg time = 2.5 lt/min x 13 min = 32.5 lt. Therefore, the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX will be: Remaining fuel at TORDU - Fuel required from TORDU to EBROX = 385 lt - 32.5 lt = 352.5 lt, which is very close to 353 lt.

You are cleared to hold at RIVER via PESER 2A arrival. When passing PESER, a fuel check reveals 5 000 kg of fuel on board. You decide to divert at 3 600 kg of fuel remaining. How long can you hold before you need to divert? Average TAS 260 kt, fuel flow 2 400 kg/h, wind 310° / 20 kt.

key_points: First Step: using the flight computer, find the Groundspeed for the track PESAR – STD and STD - RIVER
Set wind direction to 310º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
learning.explanation: First Step: using the flight computer, find the Groundspeed for the track PESAR – STD and STD - RIVER. 1. Set wind direction to 310º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. 2. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 260 kt. 3. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. 4. Initially, set the True Track under the "TRUE HEADING" index. PESAR to STAD: 306º 5. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 240 kt. STAD to RIVER: 338º 5. Note that this heading would result in 2ºR drift and a track of 340º. 6. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 338º. This occurs at a heading of 336º with 2ºR drift. 7. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 242 kt. Second Step: Find time left until diversion At PESAR we have 5000 kg and we will divert at 3600 kg. 5000 kg – 3600 kg = 1400 kg 1400 kg / 2400 kg/h = 35 minutes Third Step: Find time leg PESAR – RIVER PESAR to STAD: 13 NM / 240 kt = 3.25 min STD to RIVER: 11 NM / 242 kt = 2.73 min 2.73 + 3.25 = 5.98 approx. 6 Forth Step: Subtract time leg PESAR – RIVER from time available until 3600kg is reached – that will be the time available to holding. 35 – 6 = 29 minutes

content.question: You are flying to airport A where the weather is good. Airport B is your alternate, but it is far away. While the aircraft is near airport C, you realise that the fuel on board is actually less than the final reserve fuel. When you listen to the ATIS of airport C, you find out that the weather conditions are less than minima. What should you do in this situation?

options.A: Land in airport C since the aircraft is already in an emergency condition.
options.B: Continue to airport A since the weather is stable.
options.C: Continue to airport A as scheduled.

key_points: “Land in airport C since the aircraft is already in an emergency condition
” Incorrect
The question text states that the weather at airport C is less than minima
learning.explanation: “Land in airport C since the aircraft is already in an emergency condition.” Incorrect. The question text states that the weather at airport C is less than minima. Therefore, even if the aircraft is in an emergency situation it is not advisable to land at an airport with weather conditions lower than applicable minima. “Divert to airport B.” Incorrect. The fuel on board is less than the final reserve fuel, so it’s very much likely that it won’t be enough to reach airport B. “Continue to airport A as scheduled.” Incorrect. I believe that this option implies that the aircraft will follow the flight plan routing, which in case of emergency, does not really apply. It is likely that the aircraft will get assistance from ATC and get shortcuts, for instance. “Continue to airport A since the weather is stable.” Correct. Stable weather will permit a landing. This is the most correct option. We are trying to gather more information on this question. Therefore, we kindly ask you to send us a message or write in the comments section any information you have.

content.question:
For a planned flight the calculated fuel is as follows:
Flight time: 4 hrs 10 min
Taxi fuel: 12 kg
Block fuel: 452 kg
Reserve fuel is 30% of the Planned Trip fuel. An airborne fuel check is performed at a waypoint from which the flight time remaining to reach the destination is 1 hour 50 minutes. How much fuel should remain on board to reach the destination from this waypoint?

key_points: Take Off Fuel (TOF) = Block Fuel – (Start Up + Taxi Fuel) TOF = 452 kg – 12 kg = 440 kg Reserve fuel = 30 % of the planned Trip Fuel Flight Time: 4 h 10 min = 4
17 h Therefore, Reserve fuel = 4
17 h x 0
learning.explanation: Take Off Fuel (TOF) = Block Fuel – (Start Up + Taxi Fuel) TOF = 452 kg – 12 kg = 440 kg Reserve fuel = 30 % of the planned Trip Fuel Flight Time: 4 h 10 min = 4.17 h Therefore, Reserve fuel = 4.17 h x 0.3 = 1.25 h Total fuel onboard sufficient for = 4.17 h + 1.25 h = 5.42 h Next step: calculate the Fuel Consumption. Fuel Consumption = 440 kg / 5.42 h = 81 kg/h The aircraft has flown 4 h 10 - 1 h 50 = 2 h 20. Fuel burnt in a 2 h 20 min flight: 2 h 20 x 81 kg/h = 189 kg Fuel left for the remaining flight time (1 h 50): 440 kg – 189 kg = 251 kg

content.question: During a navigation flight, the pilot makes in-flight checks to monitor the progress of the flight. During the last leg, he/she notices that the planned timings overhead the chosen waypoints are NOT corresponding to the actual timings, and that the aircraft is getting behind the timings. Both the planned and actual airspeed are 160 kt. What is the main reason for the deviation from the planned timings?

options.A: The actual groundspeed is faster than that calculated during the planning phase.
options.B: The actual fuel consumption is different to the planned consumption.
options.C: The increase in aerodynamic drag resulting in a slower groundspeed.
options.D: The actual wind (direction or speed) is different to the forecast wind.

key_points: If the planned and actual airspeed are both 160 kt, and the pilot notices that the planned timings overhead the chosen waypoints are not corresponding to the actual timings, and that the aircraft is getting behind the timings, the main reason for the deviation from the planned timings is likely to be a headwind or tailwind component
Wind is a major factor that affects the progress of a flight, and it can cause a deviation from the planned timings
A headwind component will slow down the aircraft and increase the flight time, while a tailwind component will speed up the aircraft and decrease the flight time
learning.explanation: If the planned and actual airspeed are both 160 kt, and the pilot notices that the planned timings overhead the chosen waypoints are not corresponding to the actual timings, and that the aircraft is getting behind the timings, the main reason for the deviation from the planned timings is likely to be a headwind or tailwind component. Wind is a major factor that affects the progress of a flight, and it can cause a deviation from the planned timings. A headwind component will slow down the aircraft and increase the flight time, while a tailwind component will speed up the aircraft and decrease the flight time. The pilot should check the current wind conditions and make the necessary adjustments to the flight plan, such as adjusting the planned ground speed, fuel consumption, and arrival time. If the wind conditions are significantly different from those forecasted, the pilot may also consider diverting to an alternate airport or requesting a new clearance from ATC.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Given: Planning data as shown in the Flight Log excerpt (Fuel Planning Section). After a balked landing at the destination airport, you have to divert to the alternate airport with the gear extended.

content.question: If the actual in-flight wind produces a greater headwind than the forecast wind input into the FMC, what should be expected?

options.A: The optimum level will be lowered.
options.B: Earlier ETAs will be generated by the FMC.
options.C: A new cruise level will be generated by the FMC.
options.D: Speeds will be increased to maintain ETAs.

key_points: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains two databases: A navigation database, which is updated every 28 days, including waypoints, airways, SIDs, STARs, approach procedures, runway lengths and minimum altitudes

A performance database, which is updated only when rquired and is able to calculate maximum and optimum cruise altitudes, the optimum speeds for climb, cruise and descent and the required thrust settings for different phases of flight
The FMC has, also, the ability to calculate speeds to arrive over a waypoint at a defined time, a selection known as RTA (Required Time of Arrival)
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains two databases: A navigation database, which is updated every 28 days, including waypoints, airways, SIDs, STARs, approach procedures, runway lengths and minimum altitudes. A performance database, which is updated only when rquired and is able to calculate maximum and optimum cruise altitudes, the optimum speeds for climb, cruise and descent and the required thrust settings for different phases of flight. The FMC has, also, the ability to calculate speeds to arrive over a waypoint at a defined time, a selection known as RTA (Required Time of Arrival). In case the wind component is not as expected and input into the FMC, then it adjusts the speed so as to maintain the desired ETAs. Thus, in case the actual in-flight wind produces a greater headwind than the forecast wind input into the FMC, then speeds will be increased to maintain ETAs.

content.question: Flight planning chart for an aeroplane, states that the time to reach FL190 at a given gross mass is 22 minutes and the distance travelled is 66 NM (no wind). What will be the distance travelled with a average head wind component of 35 kt?

key_points: NGM = NAM x GS ÷ TAS NGM = NAM ± [wind component x Time (min)] ÷ 60 At first this question appears confusing

But let's start by determining the TAS at which the aircraft was flying: Time to climb = 22 min Ground distance covered = 66 nm (no wind) Speed = Distance ÷ Time (min) x 60 = 180 kt Head wind = 35 kts
A headwind does not affect the time to climb, but it will reduce the ground distance covered during the climb
learning.explanation: NGM = NAM x GS ÷ TAS NGM = NAM ± [wind component x Time (min)] ÷ 60 At first this question appears confusing. But let's start by determining the TAS at which the aircraft was flying: Time to climb = 22 min Ground distance covered = 66 nm (no wind) Speed = Distance ÷ Time (min) x 60 = 180 kt Head wind = 35 kts. A headwind does not affect the time to climb, but it will reduce the ground distance covered during the climb. Ground speed = 180 kt - 35 kt = 145 kt Now we have the necessary data to calculate the NGM: NGM = NAM x GS ÷ TAS NGM = 66 NM x 145 kt ÷ 180 kt NGM = 53 NM

learning.explanation: If the actual wind differs from the planned wind, the pilot may note the difference in the calculated times and the planned track. The actual wind will affect the groundspeed of the aircraft, which will result in a difference in the calculated times to reach a certain point along the route. This means that if the actual wind is different from the planned wind, the estimated time of arrival will be different as well. The actual wind will also affect the direction in which the aircraft is traveling over the ground, known as the track. If the pilot maintains the same heading and true airspeed, the aircraft will drift off course due to the effect of the wind, resulting in a difference in the planned track. Fuel consumption is not necessarily a reliable indicator of the difference between the planned and actual wind, as it can be affected by other factors such as altitude, temperature, and engine performance. Furthemore, in this case, it is not possible to determine whether the wind will have a positive or negative impact on fuel consumption. The difference in heading is also not a reliable indicator, as the pilot may need to adjust the heading to compensate for the effect of the wind and maintain the planned track.

key_points: This question asks for the Track Error Angle (TKE), the angle difference between the track made good and the required track, and can be solved either by using your Flight/Nav computer or applying the "1:60 rule": Flight/Nav computer method: Rotate the inner disc until the distance travelled: TAS x Time = 120 kt x 22
5/60hr = 45 NM (45) is below the distance off-track 1
learning.explanation: This question asks for the Track Error Angle (TKE), the angle difference between the track made good and the required track, and can be solved either by using your Flight/Nav computer or applying the "1:60 rule": Flight/Nav computer method: Rotate the inner disc until the distance travelled: TAS x Time = 120 kt x 22.5/60hr = 45 NM (45) is below the distance off-track 1.2 NM (12). Above the black arrow, read the TKE, 1.60º. "1:60 rule" method: Distance off track x 60 / Distance along the track = Track Error Angle (TKE) 1.2 NM x 60 / 45 NM = 1.6° Every 1 NM off-track at 60 NM equates to 1º TKE. So, 1.2 NM off-track at 45 NM equates to 1.60º TKE.

Trip Fuel: sufficient for a planned flight time of 4 hours 45 minutes
Operator’s specified Reserve Fuel: 30% of the planned Trip Fuel
Start up and Taxi Fuel: 35 kg
Block Fuel: 890 kg

key_points: Take Off Fuel (TOF) = Block Fuel – (Start Up + Taxi Fuel) TOF = 890 kg – 35 kg = 855 kg Reserve fuel = 30 % of the planned Trip Fuel Flight Time: 4h 45 min = 4
75 h Therefore, Reserve fuel = 4
75 h x 0
learning.explanation: Take Off Fuel (TOF) = Block Fuel – (Start Up + Taxi Fuel) TOF = 890 kg – 35 kg = 855 kg Reserve fuel = 30 % of the planned Trip Fuel Flight Time: 4h 45 min = 4.75 h Therefore, Reserve fuel = 4.75 h x 0.3 = 1.425 h Total fuel onboard sufficient for = 4.75 h + 1.425 h = 6.175 h Next step: calculate the Fuel Consumption. content.question:
Given the following information:
DOM: 4 565 kg
Traffic load: 2 590 kg
Remaining usable fuel: 990 kg
Remaining trip fuel to destination: 410 kg
Alternate fuel: 235 kg
Final reserve fuel: 275 kg
Calculate the revised estimated landing mass at the destination aerodrome.

key_points: "Landing Mass is the mass of the aircraft on landing, i
e
the Take-off mass less the Trip fuel and it can be calculated with various methods depending on the data given
learning.explanation: "Landing Mass is the mass of the aircraft on landing, i.e. the Take-off mass less the Trip fuel and it can be calculated with various methods depending on the data given." "Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) is the total mass of the aeroplane less the usable fuel." The fuel mass at destination will be: Remaining usable fuel - Remaining trip fuel to destination = 990 Kg - 410 Kg = 580 Kg, including both Alternate and Final Reserve fuel. Thus, the revised estimated landing mass at destination will be: Fuel mass at destination + DOM + Traffic load = 580 Kg + 4565 kg + 2590 kg = 7735 Kg. Alternatively: The Zero Fuel Mass is: DOM + Traffic load = 4565 kg + 2590 kg = 7155 kg The Fuel mass at destination will be: Remaining usable fuel - Remaining trip fuel to destination = 990 kg - 410 kg = 580 kg. Thus, the revised estimated landing mass at destination will be: ZFM + Fuel mass at destination = 7155 kg + 580 kg = 7735 kg. NOTE: Be careful to avoid any double mass calculations, due to the fact that some masses are already included in other masses.

During a flight the fuel indicators show that the remaining amount of fuel is 100 lb after 38 minutes.The total amount of fuel at take off was 160 lb. For the alternate fuel, 30 lb is necessary. The planned fuel for taxi is 13 lb. Final reserve fuel is estimated at 50 lb.
If the fuel flow remains the same, how many minutes can be flown to the destination with the remaining fuel?

key_points: (1) Calculate Trip Fuel: Take-Off Fuel: 160 lb Alternate Fuel: 30 lb Final Reserve Fuel: 50 lb Trip Fuel = Take-Off Fuel - Alternate Fuel - Final Reserve Fuel = 160 lb - 30 lb - 50 lb = 80 lb (2) Calculate Fuel Flow rate: 60 lbs of fuel were consumed in 38 min
Fuel Flow = 60 lbs / 38 min = 1
58 lbs/min (3) Calculate Total time which can be flown with Trip Fuel: Available Trip Fuel: 80 lb At a FF of 1
learning.explanation: (1) Calculate Trip Fuel: Take-Off Fuel: 160 lb Alternate Fuel: 30 lb Final Reserve Fuel: 50 lb Trip Fuel = Take-Off Fuel - Alternate Fuel - Final Reserve Fuel = 160 lb - 30 lb - 50 lb = 80 lb (2) Calculate Fuel Flow rate: 60 lbs of fuel were consumed in 38 min. Fuel Flow = 60 lbs / 38 min = 1.58 lbs/min (3) Calculate Total time which can be flown with Trip Fuel: Available Trip Fuel: 80 lb At a FF of 1.58 lbs/min, we can fly: 80 lb : 1.58 lbs/min = 50.6 min 38 min have already been flown. Therefore, we have around 50.6 min - 38 min = 12.6 min left to fly.

If the distance from destination to the alternate is 57 NM and the forecast wind was 20 kt headwind, with a TAS of 150 kt and assuming that conditions remain the same, what is the new estimated time from destination to the alternate?

key_points: Flight time = Distance / Ground Speed The forecasted wind was 20 kts Headwind
However, the wind experienced is 20 kt stronger => 40 kt Headwind
Therefore, the actual Ground Speed = 150 kt - 40 kt HDW = 110 kt New estimated time from destination to the alternate = 57 NM / 110 kt = 31 min

content.question: An aircraft flies at a TAS of 380 kt. It flies from A to B and back to A. Distance AB is 480 NM. When going from A to B, it experiences a headwind componentof 60 kt. The wind remains constant. The duration of the flight will be

key_points: On the outbound leg (from A to B), the Ground Speed will be 320 kt (True Airspeed 380 kt with a 60 kt headwind)
Covering a distance of 480 NM will take 1 hour 30 minutes (480 NM ÷ 320 kt)
Upon making a 180° turn and returning from B to A, the original 60 kt headwind transforms into a 60 kt tailwind
learning.explanation: On the outbound leg (from A to B), the Ground Speed will be 320 kt (True Airspeed 380 kt with a 60 kt headwind). Covering a distance of 480 NM will take 1 hour 30 minutes (480 NM ÷ 320 kt). Upon making a 180° turn and returning from B to A, the original 60 kt headwind transforms into a 60 kt tailwind. This results in a Ground Speed of 440 kt (True Airspeed 380 kt + 60 kt tailwind). Covering the same 480 NM at a Ground Speed of 440 kt will take 1 hour 05 minutes (480 NM ÷ 440 kt). Therefore, the total flight time from A to B and back to A will be 2 hours 35 minutes.

content.question: A pilot is planning a flight from aerodrome A to aerodrome B using aerodrome C as alternate. The distance from A to B is 120 NM on a true track 090° and the distance from B to C is 60 NM on a true track 360°. key_points: For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps twice: 1
From A to B: Set wind direction to 300º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt
learning.explanation: For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps twice: 1. From A to B: Set wind direction to 300º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 5ºR drift and a track of 095º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 090º. This occurs at a heading of 085º with 5ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 117 kt. Thus, the flight time from A to B is: 120 NM / 117 kt = 1.02 hr or 61 min. 2. From B to C: Set wind direction to 300º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt. Mark the wind velocity 20 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 360º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 10ºR drift and a track of 010º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 360º. This occurs at a heading of 350º with 10ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 89 kt. Thus, the flight time from A to B is: 60 NM / 89 kt = 0.67 hr or 40 min.

content.question: Which statement is correct regarding the altimeter temperature error correction during a final approach to an aerodrome?

options.A: Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is ISA and below and added only to the DH/DA and MDH/MDA.
options.B: Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is much lower than ISA and subtracted from the DH/DA or MDH/MDA and step-down fixes inside the FAF.
options.C: Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is ISA and below and subtracted only from the DH/DA or MDH/MDA.
options.D: Temperature error correction should be applied when the aerodrome temperature is much lower than ISA and added to the DH/DA or MDH/MDA and step-down fixes inside the FAF.

key_points: The altimeter is calibrated to standard atmosphere conditions and most of the time the environment is close enough to standard for any temperature induced errors to be minimal
When the environment is warmer than standard, the aircraft will be higher than indicated, usually a safe error
When the environment is colder than standard, the aircraft will be lower than indicated and this potentially a dangerous error
learning.explanation: The altimeter is calibrated to standard atmosphere conditions and most of the time the environment is close enough to standard for any temperature induced errors to be minimal. When the environment is warmer than standard, the aircraft will be higher than indicated, usually a safe error. When the environment is colder than standard, the aircraft will be lower than indicated and this potentially a dangerous error. Temperature errors need to be taken into account when landing in very cold conditions. A temperature correction to the DH/DA or MDA/MDH and step-down fixes inside the Final Approach Fix (FAF) must be added in this case. According to ICAO-Doc 8168-Vol.1-Flight Procedures-Part 1-Section 4-Ch. 1: The flight crew is responsible for any necessary Temperature Error Correction to all all published minimum altitudes/heights including the altitudes/heights for the initial and intermediate segments; the DA/DH and subsequent missed approach altitudes/heights except for APV/BARO-VNAV approach procedures. NOTE: The pilot is not responsible for temperature error corrections, when being radar vectored by ATC or when issued a direct routing. But this does not relieve the pilot of the responsibilty that any clearances issued by ATC are safe.
